texts.orig: author: Major Hayden date: '2022-12-12' summary: Keep your composure with diacritics, symbols, and other characters with the compose key! ⌨ tags:

texts.text: keyboard

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Much of my work is driven by my keyboard, and I love finding new ways to do complicated actions in a hurry. That's why I'm drawn towards tiling window managers like  i3  and  sway .
texts.text: Much of my work is driven by my keyboard, and I love finding new ways to do complicated actions in a hurry. That's why I'm drawn towards tiling window managers like  i3  and  sway .

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: My team at work spans the globe and speaks many different languages. Many of these languages have diacritics (such as accents, tildes, or other marks) that completely change the pronunciation  (or even the meaning!)  of the word. Sure, I can type Tomas (TOM-oss) quickly, but it's not the same as Tomaš (TOM-osh).
texts.text: My team at work spans the globe and speaks many different languages. Many of these languages have diacritics (such as accents, tildes, or other marks) that completely change the pronunciation  (or even the meaning!)  of the word. Sure, I can type Tomas (TOM-oss) quickly, but it's not the same as Tomaš (TOM-osh).

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Using diacritics shows respect for someone's name, their language and their culture. In some situations, it can be the difference between something totally normal and potentially offensive[^potatoes-and-anuses].
texts.text: Using diacritics shows respect for someone's name, their language and their culture. In some situations, it can be the difference between something totally normal and potentially offensive[^potatoes-and-anuses].

texts.orig: The old way

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I wrote about this  way back in 2020  but my main method for getting this done was using the  AltGr key .
texts.text: I wrote about this  way back in 2020  but my main method for getting this done was using the  AltGr key .

texts.text: If you want to type niños (children) in Spanish, you do this:

texts.text: Hold down the right Alt key

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Hold down the Shift key
texts.text: Hold down the Shift key

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Press the ~ key
texts.text: Press the ~ key

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Press n
texts.text: Press n

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Let go of everything and admire your ñ 😍
texts.text: Let go of everything and admire your ñ 😍

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This felt so slick and I was off to the races typing all kinds of accents and other marks. I wrote the blog post, tweeted about it, and waited for others to reply with the same excitement.
texts.text: This felt so slick and I was off to the races typing all kinds of accents and other marks. I wrote the blog post, tweeted about it, and waited for others to reply with the same excitement.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The first reply from a European was:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Nice work, but what's wrong with the compose key?
texts.text: Nice work, but what's wrong with the compose key?

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: What's a compose key? 🤔
texts.text: What's a compose key? 🤔

texts.label: title
texts.orig: Compose key
texts.text: Compose key

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I stared at my keyboard. Where is this mysterious key? I've never seen it before!
texts.text: I stared at my keyboard. Where is this mysterious key? I've never seen it before!

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Wikipedia  held the answer :
texts.text: Wikipedia  held the answer :

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Because Microsoft Windows and macOS do not support a compose key by default, the key does not exist on most keyboards designed for modern PC hardware. When software supports compose key behaviour, some other key is used. Common examples are the right-hand Windows key, the AltGr key, or one of the Ctrl keys. There is no LED or other indicator that a compose sequence is ongoing.
texts.text: Because Microsoft Windows and macOS do not support a compose key by default, the key does not exist on most keyboards designed for modern PC hardware. When software supports compose key behaviour, some other key is used. Common examples are the right-hand Windows key, the AltGr key, or one of the Ctrl keys. There is no LED or other indicator that a compose sequence is ongoing.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I get to choose the key that becomes the compose key! After asking a few Europeans about what they use on a US keyboard layout, they suggested the right CTRL key.
texts.text: I get to choose the key that becomes the compose key! After asking a few Europeans about what they use on a US keyboard layout, they suggested the right CTRL key.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: My previous blog post had an i3 configuration line like this:
texts.text: My previous blog post had an i3 configuration line like this:

texts.label: code
texts.orig: exec_always --no-startup-id "setxkbmap us -variant altgr-intl"
texts.text: exec_always --no-startup-id "setxkbmap us -variant altgr-intl"

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I figured there would need to be some kind of argument to pass to set the compose key. The man page for
texts.text: I figured there would need to be some kind of argument to pass to set the compose key. The man page for

texts.label: code
texts.orig: setxkbmap
texts.text: setxkbmap

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: says that all of the keyboard sources are in
texts.text: says that all of the keyboard sources are in

texts.label: code

texts.text: /usr/share/X11/xkb/rules

texts.orig:
> $ grep compose /usr/share/X11/xkb/rules/base.xml
          <name>mod_led:compose</name>
          <name>compose:ralt</name>
          <name>compose:lwin</name>
          <name>compose:lwin-altgr</name>
          <name>compose:rwin</name>
          <name>compose:rwin-altgr</name>
          <name>compose:menu</name>
          <name>compose:menu-altgr</name>
          <name>compose:lctrl</name>
          <name>compose:lctrl-altgr</name>
          <name>compose:rctrl</name>
          <name>compose:rctrl-altgr</name>
          <name>compose:caps</name>
          <name>compose:caps-altgr</name>
          <name>compose:102</name>
          <name>compose:102-altgr</name>
          <name>compose:paus</name>
          <name>compose:prsc</name>
          <name>compose:sclk</name>
texts.text:
> $ grep compose /usr/share/X11/xkb/rules/base.xml
          <name>mod_led:compose</name>

          <name>compose:lwin</name>
          <name>compose:lwin-altgr</name>

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Opening that file shows the specific
texts.text: Opening that file shows the specific

texts.label: code
texts.orig: rctrl
texts.text: rctrl

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: option:
texts.text: option:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
<configItem>
  <name>Compose key</name>
  <description>Position of Compose key</description>
</configItem>
<!--- SNIP --->
<option>
  <configItem>
    <name>compose:rctrl</name>
    <description>Right Ctrl</description>
  </configItem>
</option>
texts.text:
<configItem>
  <name>Compose key</name>
  <description>Position of Compose key</description>
</configItem>
<!--- SNIP --->
<option>
  <configItem>
    <name>compose:rctrl</name>
    <description>Right Ctrl</description>
  </configItem>
</option>

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: My new i3 line looks like this:
texts.text: My new i3 line looks like this:

texts.label: code
texts.orig: exec_always --no-startup-id "setxkbmap us -variant altgr-intl -option compose:rctrl"
texts.text: exec_always --no-startup-id "setxkbmap us -variant altgr-intl -option compose:rctrl"

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Now I get the best of both worlds:
texts.text: Now I get the best of both worlds:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: I can still use the Alt+Gr key for muscle memory.
texts.text: I can still use the Alt+Gr key for muscle memory.

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: The compose key gives me access to more characters with less keypresses!
texts.text: The compose key gives me access to more characters with less keypresses!

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: There's a  long list  of symbols you can type with your compose key!
texts.text: There's a  long list  of symbols you can type with your compose key!

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: [^potatoes-and-anuses]: Just check out  años versus anos  in Español. 😉 🥔
texts.text: [^potatoes-and-anuses]: Just check out  años versus anos  in Español. 😉 🥔
